Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2012 12:46PM Ella_117 wrote: Hi Susan, The dreaded steroid induced insomnia was the worst part of the entire chemo experience for me. It was torture. I had 16 chemos ....first AC dose dense every 2 weeks, followed by weekly Taxol and Herceptin. Towards the end of my treatment my onc cut the steroid dose in half and as a result it really helped alleviate the insomnia issues. Fortunately, once treatments are over the insomnia does goes away. I did not start losing my hair until the 21st day and even then, I had quite a bit of hair left that hung on, and looked good sticking out under hats. Finally a month later, i did lose most, but soon after my hair surprisingly started to grow back during my 12 weekly taxol treatment. It was such a welcomed surprise that I had never expected! As for hair suggestions....after purchasing a number of expensive wigs than had what I know now to be really fake looking hairlines... Another woman on these boards turned me on to a great wig company called Estetica Designs, which offers a complete line of wigs called the naturalle collection that feature absolutely amazing styles!! You can actually pull your hair back and you cannot tell that it is not your real hairline coming out of your scalp!!! The new wig technology is amazing and even fun......Some of the wig names are Monica, Blake, sienna, and many more .....,that can be ordered online at a reasonable price about $150 and under range with many colors to choose from. You can check out their website by typing in estetica design wigs. Good luck, and i hope you begin to feel better each day.

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2013 03:15PM Ella_117 wrote: milane, So sorry to hear you are going thru this! I had a similar experience....after my first biopsy came back positive the surgeon ordered an MRI and 2 additional spots lit up. I had to then have 2 more biopsies...it was so stressful and painful...but both spots turned out to be false positives. The one spot couldn't even be picked up on ultrasound, but since it lit up on MRI the surgeon was obligated to then determine the nature of the tumor with needle biopsy. The doctor told me that he really hesitates to order MRIs because they have a very high false positive rate. I hope yours turn out to also be false positives. In the end I was glad to have had the MRI because I have very dense breasts and it provided a baseline for future imaging. {{Hugs}}
